Award.AwardTitle: Heat and Charge Transport and Coupling in Quantum-Confined Nanowires

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET- 1336428
PI: Chen

In dielectric materials, such as semiconductors, heat is conducted by phonons (lattice vibrations). When the characteristic length scale of a solid is comparable to phonon wavelength, which for most semiconductors is in the range of 1 to 10 nm, a new regime referred to as the ?phonon confinement? regime arises. This regime has yet to be accessed experimentally but will provide tremendous insight into the fundamentals of energy transport and conversion. The goal of this project will be to probe the phonon confinement regime for the first time with the following objectives: 1) Develop a high-resolution resistive thermometry scheme capable of resolving sub-picowatt/Kelvin (pW/K) thermal conductance, in order to probe nanowires with diameter down to 5 nm, which will possess thermal conductance on the order of 10 pW/K; 2) Study thermal transport in single-component and core-shell nanowires in the phonon confinement regime, in order to elucidate the effects of confinement and boundary scattering on thermal transport, as well as explore the prospect of phononic engineering through heterostructures; 3) Investigate carrier and thermoelectric transport in the quantum confinement regime to understand low dimensional charge transport and electron-phonon coupling.


Thermal energy transport and conversion phenomena are ubiquitous in a variety of technologies, such as heat generation and dissipation in computing and communication devices and thermoelectric waste heat scavenging. As the trend of miniaturization continues, the size of various functional structures is approaching the scale of phonon wavelength. This project will enhance our understanding of fundamental thermal energy transport and conversion processes in the quantum confinement regime. Subsequently, this understanding will enable us to engineer thermal and thermoelectric properties beyond the classical size effect regime, which could impact important thermal technologies such as thermal insulation, thermoelectrics, and thermal management. The research undertaken in this project will also train students in the interdisciplinary fields of nano-science and heat transfer. Furthermore, opportunities to engage and educate local disadvantaged high school and undergraduate students will be supported through this project in conjunction with outreach programs at the UCSD campus.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this project is to probe and understand nanoscale heat transfer in the confinement regime using ultra-thin nanostructures. The project has been very fruitful, leading to several significant research and educational achievements.

One the research front, we have accomplished the following outcomes:

1). Developed ultra- sensitive calorimetry platform that is capable of measuring nanostructures with thermal conductance down to 0.25 picoWatt/Kelvin [1, 2]. Also developed the first platform to simultaneously measure thermal conductivity and specific heat of individual nanowires and nanofibers[3].

2). Studied thermal transport in ultra-thin Si nanotubes, and discovered a new mechanism to suppress phonon transport in nanowires, the elastic softening effect, which is induced by the presence of a soft surface layer[4].

3) Systematically characterized the electrical transport properties of crystalline and amorphous Si nanotube using a field effect transistor configuration [5].

4). Identified the role of structural alignment in polymer nanofibers on thermal conductivity through systematic thermal transport and structural characterizations (wide angle X-ray scattering) on single polymer nanofibers [6].

5). Studied phonon transport in multilayers with ultra-thin layer thickness (down to 3 nm), in which the interfacial thermal resistance is dominant. Revealed the close relationship between the ultra-low thermal conductivity and the large contrast in Debye temperature of the individual layers (e.g., Au and Si) [7] .

6). Systematically measured size dependent thermal conductivity in amorphous Si with size range of 5 nanometers to ~2 microns, and mapped the mean free path distribution of propagons (phonon-like low frequency modes) in [8].  

7). Studied and elucidated the mechanism leading to self-bridging of vertical silicon nanowires by using a universal capacitive force model[9] .

8). Contributed to the broad field of nanoscale energy transport and conversion by publishing review articles on topics of phonon transport in the “confinement” regime [10] and in amorphous materials [11].

In addition to publication in peer-reviewed scientific journals, the PIs and graduate students have also delivered numerous presentations in scientific and technical conferences, such as ASME and MRS meetings, including more than ten invited talks given by the PI.  The PI and the Co-PI have also published two book chapters on thermal transport and thermoelectrics, in part based on the results obtained from this project.

The project has trained graduate students in the interdisciplinary area of phonon physics, materials science, and energy technology. The scientific outcomes of the project formed the basis for two doctoral dissertations. Another PhD student, who is a female, was also partially supported by the grant and joined the faculty at University of Nevada upon graduation.

Furthermore, by leveraging several outreach programs at UCSD, the project has served as an effective platform for recruiting undergraduate and high school students. Each summer, we have recruited at least two high school from underrepresented groups to participate in summer research internships, including one two African American students and two Hispanic students. We also hosted a large number (over six) of undergraduates for their research projects. Several of these undergraduate went on to attend graduate schools in Engineering.
